ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the story The Busy Tree. We learned about animal homes. We talked about why animals need homes. Plants and animals are living things. They start small and grow up. This is called the life cycle.
In this activity, we will look at pictures of living things. You will tell me if the picture shows a plant or an animal. Then we will line up all the pictures into two groups: “Plants” or“Animals.”

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Sort Give the picture card to a child to line up in the animals or plants row.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.
Talk about Plants and Animals Point to the row of cards on the “Plant” side. All the pictures here are plants. They are part of a tree’s life cycle. Repeat for animals.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: All of the pictures show times in the life cycles of different plants and animals. Let’s talk about what happens to the plants’ and animals’ life cycles in each of the pictures.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Show children two plant cards and one animal card. Encourage children to choose the card that does not belong.

Place all cards face up on the table. Point to each card and say, Is this from the tree’s, moth’s, or bird’s life cycle? After placing each card in one of these categories, ask children to tell why they placed the card where they did.

Have children respond non-verbally by pointing and placing cards into correct categories. Ask questions with the target words, for example, Is this caterpillar part of the moth’s life cycle? Encourage children to respond in simple words and phrases. To put the cards in order, repeat the process, asking, Is this caterpillar near the beginning of the life cycle?

Place all the cards face up in a scrambled arrangement on the table. Let each child pick up one card at a time and place it approximately where it would go in a 3 x 3 arrangement, with one row of three cards for each life form. Have children continue taking turns moving the cards until each card is in the correct order in the correct row.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Magnifying Glasses, seeds, rocks, dirt, different size, texture, and color leaves, and whatever materials you can find outside.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read The Busy Tree. This book is about a tree that looks still from a distance; but up close, it’s busy.
We talked about being curious. When you are curious, you ask questions. We have some questions about things we saw in the book.
We also learned the word focus today. Let’s revisit the word because it has something to do with our activity today. Revisit the focus Vocabulary Card.

In this activity, we will use our Magnifying Glasses to focus on some of the things we saw in The Busy Tree, and other things we find outside. We will talk about what we learned when we focused, and ask questions about what we are still curious about.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Focus! Give each child a Magnifying Glass. Organize children in pairs to examine one of the natural objects closely for a minute or two. Encourage them to talk about what they see. Then ask children to look without the Magnifying Glass and talk about what they see.
Repeat Continue the activity until each pair of children has a chance to look at each object under the magnifier.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When you look through a Magnifying Glass you can see more detail. Look at something that you are curious about. What special details did you see when you looked at it through the Magnifying Glass?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Encourage children to say what they see through their Magnifying Glasses, modeling language to describe the details that are revealed under magnification. Model curiosity by asking questions about what you see.

Challenge children to compare the natural objects they are examining to the same/similar objects in the book. Ask them to consider which details in both versions are the same and which are different. Suggest they may want to read another book about the things they are looking at.

To help them express their curiosity, provide sentence starters for multilingual learners, such as: I wonder why/how ? Model using these sentence starters as you look at objects with a child, asking Do you wonder that too? Insert the English words and phrases the child produces in these sentence frames, and invite the child to repeat the sentence.

Offer additional sensory support by inviting children to smell and gently touch the objects. Consider moving the activity outdoors and letting children hunt for their own leaves, seeds, and other objects. Encourage children to talk about what they discover when they use their senses. Model sentences starters, for example: It looks . It smells . It feels .

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read The Busy Tree and talked about animal homes. We also played a little game where we looked for Scout.
Prepositions tell us where something is. For example, prepositions can tell us if something is in, on, under, or behind something else.
In this activity, we will look at pictures of animal homes. Then we will ask and answer questions to say what the animal is doing and where it’s doing it!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card and ask a child the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

Talk About Prepositions All of the prepositions we used told where the animals were: in, on, under, behind, and through. We are discovering that you can use more than one word to talk about the same place. Choose different objects in the classroom and have children take turns explaining where the object is by using a preposition. Model for children.
Read aloud the Ask and Support sections of each card. Then, ask children to tell what else they know about the animal in the photo, or to ask questions. Encourage as much conversation as possible.

Challenge children to add more phrases about where an animal is. Children can use details from the picture and their imaginations. For example, “The chameleon is resting on a branch of a tree in the jungle.” Help children find the right preposition to describe where the animal is.

Let children use a physical response, in addition to speaking, to talk about the location of the animals in the pictures. For example, set an empty tissue box and a small plastic animal on the table and let children set the animal at the location in relation to the box that is closest to the animal’s location in the picture.

Do the activity outside near a play structure or in the room’s large motor play area. Have children pretend to be the animal in the card and sit in, on, under, or behind structures as they describe the animal’s location in a sentence.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read At the Pond and noticed how it was like The Busy Tree. We noticed that some words, such as nests, can mean two different things.
In this activity, we will look at pictures of things that show the same word used in two ways. Then we will act out each meaning.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Multiple-Meaning Words Remember the word nest. It can be a thing, like the nest that a bird makes. It can also be an animal sitting comfortably in a safe place. A lot of words mean more than one thing. Revisit multiple-meaning words by sharing the Multiple-Meaning Strategy Card.
Organize Plan to show the first card of the first pair, then the second card of the first pair, then the first card of the second pair, and so on.
Ask Show the first card and ask a child the question on the back, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we see words like these in a story, how do we know which meaning to use? Sometimes looking at the pictures in the story can help.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: For younger or developmentally delayed children, read aloud the Ask and Support sections of each card. Let the child act out the word first. Supply the word for the child if necessary, and have the child repeat it. Encourage as much conversation as possible.

Challenge children to generate more multiple-meaning words. Other multiple-meaning words are anchor and bark from A Busy Tree (pages 4 and 11). Children may mention words that sound the same but are spelled differently (eight/ate). Accept as age appropriate.

Multilingual learners may benefit from hearing and using multiple-meaning words in more than one frame sentence. For example, after presenting the frame, This is a tree tr (trunk), provide a frame in the form of a question: Have you ever touched a tree tr (trunk)? Present multiple frames for other words as well.

Provide paper and crayons, and have children draw each meaning of the word in a single image (like a person fishing for a fish). Ask children to describe their drawings, encouraging them to use each multiple-meaning word in more than one way.
